Rustic Chicken & Potato Bowl

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to your new favorite weeknight dinner recipe: the Rustic Chicken & Potato Bowl! This delightful dish combines juicy, boneless, skinless chicken breasts with perfectly roasted baby potatoes and vibrant mixed vegetables, creating a wholesome meal that is both satisfying and easy to prepare. Whether you're a busy parent looking for a quick meal or a culinary enthusiast wanting to impress at the dinner table, this recipe has something for everyone. With just a handful of ingredients and under an hour of cooking time, you'll be able to serve up a delicious, nutritious dinner that the whole family will love. Plus, the use of simple seasonings like garlic powder and paprika elevates the flavors without overwhelming your palate. Get ready to enjoy a hearty bowl of goodness that's not only visually appealing but also packed with essential nutrients. Let's dive into the recipe for this Rustic Chicken & Potato Bowl and discover how easy it is to create a comforting meal right at home!

Ingredients

boneless, skinless chicken breasts

Choose chicken that is firm and has a pink color without any dark spots. For substitutions, you can use boneless, skinless thighs for a juicier option. To enhance flavor, marinate the chicken in your choice of spices or a bit of lemon juice before cooking.

baby potatoes

Look for potatoes that are smooth and firm. You can substitute with fingerling potatoes or even regular potatoes, just cut them into smaller pieces. To enhance flavor, consider tossing them with fresh herbs or garlic before roasting.

olive oil

Extra virgin olive oil is ideal for flavor, but regular olive oil works too. If you need a substitution, avocado oil or canola oil can be used. To enhance flavor, infuse the olive oil with herbs or garlic before using it in cooking.

garlic powder

Garlic powder offers a concentrated garlic flavor. If you don't have it, you can substitute with fresh minced garlic (about 1 clove equals 1/8 tsp garlic powder). To enhance the garlic flavor, consider toasting the powder in the oil before adding it to other ingredients.

paprika

Choose sweet paprika for a milder flavor or smoked paprika for a deeper, smoky taste. If unavailable, you can substitute with cayenne pepper for heat or chili powder. To enhance flavor, add a touch of lemon zest or vinegar to balance the smokiness.

salt

Use kosher salt for even seasoning. If you're watching sodium intake, consider using a salt substitute or herbs to enhance flavor. To enhance the overall taste, try using flavored salts, like garlic or herb-infused.

black pepper

Freshly ground black pepper adds more flavor than pre-ground. If unavailable, white pepper is a good substitute, though it has a different taste. To enhance its flavor, consider adding a pinch of freshly grated nutmeg for warmth.

mixed vegetables (zucchini, bell peppers, etc.)

Use any combination of seasonal vegetables for freshness. Substitutions can include broccoli, carrots, or snap peas. To enhance flavor, consider adding a splash of soy sauce or balsamic vinegar during sautéing.

fresh parsley (for garnish)

Choose bright green parsley with no yellowing leaves. Substitute with other fresh herbs like cilantro or basil for a different flavor profile. To enhance flavor, chop and mix the parsley with a bit of lemon juice and zest before garnishing.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Preheat the Oven

    Start by preheating your oven to 400°F (200°C). This ensures that once you place your potatoes inside, they roast evenly and achieve a delicious crispy exterior.

  • Step 2: Prepare the Baby Potatoes

    Wash 1 lb of baby potatoes thoroughly under cold water. Cut each potato in half to allow for even cooking and better flavor absorption. Place them in a mixing bowl.

  • Step 3: Season the Potatoes

    Drizzle the halved potatoes with 1 tablespoon of olive oil. Add 1 tsp of garlic powder, 1 tsp of paprika, 1 tsp of salt, and 1/2 tsp of black pepper. Toss everything together until the potatoes are well coated. This step is crucial for flavor, so ensure that every piece is evenly seasoned.

  • Step 4: Roast the Potatoes

    Spread the seasoned potatoes out on a baking sheet in a single layer. Roast in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. This will give them a nice golden-brown color and crispy texture. Tip: You can add some herbs like rosemary or thyme for extra flavor!

  • Step 5: Season the Chicken Breasts

    While the potatoes are roasting, take 2 boneless, skinless chicken breasts and season both sides with salt, pepper, and a sprinkle of paprika for a hint of color and flavor.

  • Step 6: Cook the Chicken

    In a large skillet, heat the remaining tablespoon of olive oil over medium heat. Once hot, add the seasoned chicken breasts. Cook for about 6-7 minutes on each side, or until they are golden brown and cooked through (internal temperature should reach 165°F/75°C). Remove the chicken from the skillet and let it rest. Resting allows the juices to redistribute, keeping the chicken moist.

  • Step 7: Sauté the Mixed Vegetables

    In the same skillet, add 2 cups of mixed vegetables (like zucchini and bell peppers). Sauté for about 5-7 minutes until they are tender. This not only saves time but also enhances the flavor with the leftover chicken juices.

  • Step 8: Assemble the Rustic Chicken & Potato Bowl

    Slice the rested chicken breasts and layer them over the roasted potatoes. Top with the sautéed vegetables and garnish with 1/4 cup of fresh parsley. This adds a pop of color and freshness to your dish.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I properly wash and cut vegetables like baby potatoes?

Start by rinsing the baby potatoes under cold running water to remove any dirt. Then, use a cutting board and a sharp knife to halve them. If they are larger, you can quarter them for quicker cooking.

How can I tell when chicken is cooked through?

The best way to check if chicken is cooked is to use a meat thermometer. It should read 165°F (75°C) at the thickest part. If you don't have one, the chicken should be no longer pink in the center and the juices should run clear.

What’s the best way to season my chicken?

A simple seasoning of salt, pepper, and a sprinkle of paprika works wonders. Use about 1/2 teaspoon of salt and pepper per chicken breast, and adjust to your taste.

How do I know when my potatoes are done roasting?

Roasted potatoes are done when they are golden brown and can be easily pierced with a fork. This usually takes about 15-20 minutes in a hot oven.

What’s the importance of letting chicken rest after cooking?

Letting chicken rest for a few minutes after cooking allows the juices to redistribute, making it more tender and juicy when you slice it.

How do I safely handle raw chicken in the kitchen?

Always wash your hands before and after handling raw chicken. Use separate cutting boards for raw meat and vegetables to prevent cross-contamination.

Can I use frozen vegetables instead of fresh ones?

Yes, you can! Just make sure to thaw them beforehand and adjust the cooking time slightly if they are still frozen.

Why is it important to preheat the oven?

Preheating the oven ensures that your food cooks evenly and at the right temperature from the start, which is especially important for roasting.

What can I substitute for olive oil?

You can use other oils like vegetable oil, canola oil, or even melted butter if you prefer. Each will add a slightly different flavor.

How do I garnish my dish with parsley?

To garnish with fresh parsley, simply wash it, pat it dry, and chop it finely. Sprinkle it over the top of your dish just before serving for a fresh touch.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This dish can easily be adapted for various dietary preferences. For a gluten-free option, ensure that all seasonings and oils are certified gluten-free. To make it dairy-free, simply omit any cheese. For a vegetarian version, substitute the chicken with chickpeas or a plant-based protein, and replace the chicken broth with vegetable broth when cooking the vegetables. Also, ensure that any pre-packaged mixed vegetables do not contain any added animal products.

Pairings

For a heartier meal, consider pairing the Rustic Chicken & Potato Bowl with roasted or grilled asparagus or a fresh garden salad drizzled with a light vinaigrette. To complement the flavors, serve with a crisp white wine like Sauvignon Blanc or a light-bodied red like Pinot Noir. For a non-alcoholic option, a sparkling water with a splash of lemon or a refreshing iced herbal tea would enhance the dish beautifully.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Rustic Chicken & Potato Bowl in shallow bowls or plates to showcase the colorful layers of roasted potatoes, sliced chicken, and sautéed vegetables. Garnish generously with fresh parsley for a pop of color. Consider adding a squeeze of fresh lemon juice over the top just before serving to brighten the flavors. If desired, sprinkle with grated Parmesan cheese or crumbled feta for an extra layer of flavor. For a rustic touch, serve with warm crusty bread or garlic bread on the side.

#

Rustic Chicken & Potato Bowl

45 min
$12.5
550 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 2

Dietary Tags:

High ProteinGluten-Free

Cuisine:

American

Course:

Main Course

Tags:

EasyComfort FoodOne-Pan Meal

Description

A hearty and comforting bowl filled with tender chicken, roasted potatoes, and seasonal vegetables, all drizzled with a flavorful herb dressing.

Ingredients

  • boneless, skinless chicken breasts: 2
  • baby potatoes: 1 lb
  • olive oil: 2 tbsp
  • garlic powder: 1 tsp
  • paprika: 1 tsp
  • salt: 1 tsp
  • black pepper: 1/2 tsp
  • mixed vegetables (zucchini, bell peppers, etc.): 2 cups
  • fresh parsley (for garnish): 1/4 cup

Date Created:

11/18/2024
